title: Houston-area police arrest man for killing American Bald Eagle
text:

Harris County recently arrested a 17-year-old male after authorities said he shot and killed a bald eagle.

Status: Endangered (Federal list) Photo: Courtesy /, Texas Wildlife Image 31 of 38 White-tailed Hawk Status: Threatened White-tailed Hawk Status: Threatened Photo: Danita Delimont, Texas Wildlife Image 32 of 38 Widemouth Blindcat Status: Threatened Widemouth Blindcat Status: Threatened Photo: Texas Wildlife Image 33 of 38 Texas Indigo Snake Status: Threatened Texas Indigo Snake Status: Threatened Photo: Jeremy Woodhouse, Texas Wildlife Image 34 of 38 Mexican Burrowing Toad Status: Threatened (Getty Images) Mexican Burrowing Toad Status: Threatened (Getty Images) Photo: Geoff Brightling, Texas Wildlife Image 35 of 38 Texas Horned Lizard Status: Threatened Texas Horned Lizard Status: Threatened Photo: George Brits, Texas Wildlife Image 36 of 38 Red-cockaded Woodpecker Status: Endangered Red-cockaded Woodpecker Status: Endangered Photo: Nick De La Torre, Texas Wildlife Image 37 of 38 Gray Hawk Status: Threatened Gray Hawk Status: Threatened Photo: Kathy Adams Clark Image 38 of 38 Houston-area police arrest man for killing American Bald Eagle 1 / 38 Back to Gallery The Harris County Sheriff's Office recently arrested 17-year-old Orlando David Delgado who is charged with shooting and killing a bald eagle with two of his friends.
A resident in North Harris county said he heard a "loud pop" near his home and observed three males standing near a tree where the symbolic bird had nested for a few years.
SURVIVING TEXAS: How to stay safe vs. the Lone Star State's biggest threats
When the witness approached, he saw the eagle's body and dialed 911-- but not before the three males nabbed one of the eagle's feathers and took off in a white colored truck.
After identifying the vehicle, police arrested the teen, who told them he shot the eagle several times with a high-powered Gammo Pellet rifle.
The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service chose not to prosecute Delgado due to his age, authorities said. Instead, Game Warden H.R. Volschenk of the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department charged the minor with a class A misdemeanor for hunting without a landowner's consent.
REPEALED: Endangered Species Act may be heading for the threatened list
Click through above to see endangered species of Texas.
Photographer Tasha Hall captured the incredible moment her family helped save a bald eagle trapped in a hunterâ€™s snare on January 26.Hall wrote that she had been on a snowmobile expedition in Kootenays, British Columbia, to photograph moose when she stumbled across the stricken eagle. The video shows they freed the eagle from the snare and used a jacket to calm and restrain the injured raptor. CTV News reported that the eagle was treated for dehydration and a wing hematoma at the BC Wildlife Park, and staff hoped the bird can eventually be released back into the wild. This video shows the rescue. Credit: BC Farm & Family Photography via Storyful
Media: MediaOS Video Check out the video above to see a photographer rescue a bald eagle.
